This was the first time they have returned to the streets since the crackdown by the [[Military dictatorship|junta]] in September.<ref name="yahoo">{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/rtrs/20071031/tpl-uk-myanmar-monks-43a8d4f_4.html|title=Yahoo News UK & Ireland – Latest World News & UK News Headlines|publisher=uk.news.yahoo.com|accessdate=16 May 2015}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> One monk who was on the march told the [[Democratic Voice of Burma]], a Norway-based radio station run by dissident journalists: "We are continuing our protest from last month as we have not yet achieved any of the demands we asked for. Our demands are for lower commodity prices, national reconciliation and immediate release of [pro-democracy leader] [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] and all the political prisoners." Thai-based director of the Human Rights Education Institute of Burma, Aung Nyo Min, said "This is very significant... we are very encouraged to see the monks are taking up action and taking up peaceful demonstrations in Burma."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7070551.stm Monks return to streets of Burma] BBC. Retrieved 2 November 2007.</ref>
====2 November 2007==== The Burma government is to expel the United Nations' top diplomat in the country, UN officials have said. The military regime told UN's Burma country chief, [[Charles Petrie (diplomat)|Charles Petrie]], his mandate was not going to be renewed. It is not clear when he will have to leave. Mr Petrie is known to have voiced concerns over the [[Military dictatorship|junta]]'s violent break-up of peaceful demonstrations in September: "The events clearly demonstrated the everyday struggle to meet basic needs and the urgent necessity to address the deteriorating humanitarian situation in the country," Mr Petrie's statement said, 24 October, [[United Nations Day]]. The US called the expulsion an outrage and an insult.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7075294.stm Burma to expel UN's top diplomat] [[BBC]]. Retrieved 2 November 2007.</ref>
====7 November 2007==== Burma's military rulers have given a date for United Nations human rights envoy Paulo Sérgio Pinheiro to begin a five-day visit on 11 and 15 November. Pinheiro, known officially as the UN's special rapporteur on human rights in Burma, has warned: "If they don't give me full co-operation, I'll go to the plane, and I'll go out." Pinheiro had been refused entry since 2003. His visit comes before a meeting of the Association of South-East Asian Nations ([[Asean]]).<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7080732.stm UN rights chief given Burma date] BBC. Retrieved 7 November 2007.</ref>
====September 2008==== [[File:Stop hand caution.svg|thumb|right|100px|A stop symbol]] One year after the protests started, small acts of defiance continued. In particular, a 'stop sign' (the palm of a raised hand inside a circle) is being stamped onto banknotes and other places as a reminder of the protests.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article4828978.ece 'In tiny acts of defiance, a revolution still fickers], ''[[The Times]]'', 26 September 2008.</ref> Several bomb attacks also took place at [[Yangon]] throughout the month which the junta blamed was carried out by the [[National League for Democracy|NLD]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.burmanet.org/news/2008/10/21/agence-france-presse-myanmar-blast-victim-was-ex-monk-turned-bombmaker-state-media/|title=Myanmar blast victim was ex-monk turned bombmaker: state media|last=|first=|date=21 October 2008|work=|publisher=BurmaNet News|agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|access-date=3 December 2016|via=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203130036/http://www.burmanet.org/news/2008/10/21/agence-france-presse-myanmar-blast-victim-was-ex-monk-turned-bombmaker-state-media/|archive-date=3 December 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====October 2008==== On 19 October 2008 a bomb exploded in the Htan Chauk Pin quarter of the [[Shwepyitha Township]] of [[Yangon]], near the office of the military junta-backed [[Union Solidarity and Development Association]] killing one.<ref>{{cite news|title=One Dead in Burma Blasts|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/bombs-10202008121201.html|accessdate=3 December 2016|agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|publisher=Radio Free Asia|date=20 October 2008}}</ref> According to the [[New Light of Myanmar]], the victim was identified as Thet Oo Win, a former Buddhist monk who participated in the Saffron Revolution, was killed while improvising the bomb at his own residence.<ref name=":0">{{cite news|title=Increasing bomb blasts worry Rangoon residents – Zarni & Mungpi|url=http://www.burmanet.org/news/2008/10/21/mizzima-news-increasing-bomb-blasts-worry-rangoon-residents-zarni-mungpi/|accessdate=3 December 2016|agency=Mizzima News|issue=1|publisher=BurmaNet News|date=21 October 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203125805/http://www.burmanet.org/news/2008/10/21/mizzima-news-increasing-bomb-blasts-worry-rangoon-residents-zarni-mungpi/|archive-date=3 December 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The junta blamed the [[National League for Democracy]] party of planting that bomb, but experts believed at the time that the opposition was not in a position to carry out such acts amidst the tightly controlled security environment.<ref name=":0" />
==Casualties== {{Politics of Burma}} The number of casualties is not yet clear.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071001/ap_on_re_as/myanmar_dead___missing_1;_ylt=AsArorhaU7exPZMmVHFsc5SROrgF Groups struggle to tally Myanmar's dead]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Yahoo News, 1 October 2007</ref> According to [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC]], the military crackdown claimed hundreds of lives. The official toll remains at 13 killed.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/09/28/2046819.htm More Burma protesters arrested as curfew orders ignored] ABC News Australia</ref> [[Kenji Nagai]], the Japanese photo journalist, is believed to currently be the only foreign casualty of the unrest. However, it is possible that the death toll may be many times greater than officially reported.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071210103000/http://www.forbes.com/afxnewslimited/feeds/afx/2007/09/28/afx4165836.html Death Toll may be higher than reported] ''Forbes''</ref>
Speaking before the UN General Assembly, the UN Human Rights Council's Special Rapporteur Paulo Sérgio Pinheiro said that independent sources reported 30 to 40 monks and 50 to 70 civilians killed as well as 200 beaten.<ref>{{cite press release | title = Myanmar: UN rights expert to probe allegations of abuses during crackdown | publisher=UN News Centre | date = 25 October 2007 | url = https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=24405&Cr=myanmar&Cr1= | accessdate =25 October 2007}}</ref>
[[Democratic Voice of Burma]] puts the number of deaths at 138, basing their figure on a list compiled by the 88 Student Generation group in Myanmar. The Executive Director of the DVB, Aye Chan Naing, told the Associated Press that "[t]his 138 figure is quite credible because it is based on names of victims, I also think the figure is accurate because of the pictures coming from inside Burma. The way they were shooting into the crowds with machine guns means dozens of people could have died."<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071001/ap_on_re_as/myanmar_dead___missing_1;_ylt=AsArorhaU7exPZMmVHFsc5SROrgF Groups struggle to tally Myanmar's dead]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''Yahoo News'', 1 October 2007</ref>
A report in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' states that "[t]housands of protesters are dead and the bodies of hundreds of executed monks have been dumped in the jungle", the report is based on information provided by Colonel Hla Win, who defected from the army some days prior to the report, he is quoted as having said "Many more people have been killed in recent days than you've heard about. The bodies can be counted in several thousand.".<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/worldnews.html?in_article_id=484903&in_page_id=1811&ct=5 Burma: Thousands dead in massacre of the monks dumped in the jungle] ''Daily Mail'', 1 October 2007</ref>
Australia's ''[[The Age]]'' reports that, after two non-protesters were shot in northwest Yangon, "the army came back, gave the families 20,000 kyat (~$20) each and took away the corpses."<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/as-burmas-junta-reclaims-streets-locals-stand-up-for-monks/2007/10/01/1191091027787.html As Burma's junta reclaims streets, locals stand up for monks] ''The Age'', 2 October 2007</ref>
Reports forwarded by ''Times Online'' stated that the abbot of Ngwe Kyar Yan monastery in north west Yangon was so severely beaten by soldiers "that he died on the spot"; the soldiers had been lining monks up against a wall and smashing each of their heads against the wall in succession before throwing them into trucks.<ref name="TO"/>
The final death toll still remained 31 confirmed by the UN human rights envoy to Burma, [[Paulo Sergio Pinheiro]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7133239.stm Burma Toll at least 31 UN say] BBC News, 7 December 2007</ref>
==Arrests and releases== On 7 October [[Al Jazeera]] News reported that at least 1,000 people had been arrested. This figure was provided by Burma's state-run media, the [[New Light of Myanmar]]. On 11 October state media reported new figures – that 2,100 people have been arrested and 700 already released.<ref name="Time-Oct – 12">{{cite news|title=US Diplomat Meets Burma Leader |agency=Associated Press |work=Time |date=12 October 2007 |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1670854,00.html |accessdate=10 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080726123219/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0%2C8599%2C1670854%2C00.html |archivedate=26 July 2008 |df= }}</ref> In contrast, foreign sources claim that more than 6,000 people are being held.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/29937688-3110-44F7-A642-502D905F8542.htm AJE – Al Jazeera English] Aljazeera News, More protesters held in Myanmar.</ref> London-based business news agency [[Reuters]] reported about 80 monks and 149 women (believed to be Buddhist nuns) were released by the junta on 3 October 2007.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7025357.stm BBC NEWS | Asia-Pacific | Monks 'trying to escape Rangoon'] BBC News, More monk escape</ref>
On 11 November 2008, a court in [[Insein Prison]] sentenced 14 [[88 Generation Students Group]] members (Arnt Bwe Kyaw, Kyaw Kyaw Htwe aka Marky, [[Kyaw Min Yu]] aka Jimmy, Mar Mar Oo,<ref>{{cite news | title = Mar Mar Oo Profile | author=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) | publisher=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) |url = http://aappb.org/biography_2.html| accessdate= 5 November 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101104210948/http://www.aappb.org/biography_2.html| archivedate= 4 November 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref> Min Zeya, [[Nilar Thein]],<ref>{{cite news | title = Nilar Thein Profile | author=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) | publisher=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) |url = http://aappb.org/biography_2.html| accessdate= 5 November 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101104210948/http://www.aappb.org/biography_2.html| archivedate= 4 November 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref> Pannate Tun, [[Sanda Min]] aka Shwee,<ref>{{cite news | title = Sandar Min Profile | author=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) | publisher=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) |url = http://aappb.org/biography_2.html| accessdate= 5 November 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101104210948/http://www.aappb.org/biography_2.html| archivedate= 4 November 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref> Than Tin aka Kyee Than, Thet Thet Aung,<ref>{{cite news | title = Thet Thet Aung Profile | author=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) | publisher=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma) |url = http://aappb.org/biography_2.html| accessdate= 5 November 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101104210948/http://www.aappb.org/biography_2.html| archivedate= 4 November 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref> Thin Thin Aye aka [[Mie Mie]], Thet Zaw, Zaw Zaw Min and Zay Ya aka Kalama)<ref>[http://www.aappb.org Home] Assistance Association of Political Prisoners</ref> arrested during the anti-government protests to 65 years in prison. The government used a variety of laws including the ''foreign exchange act'' and the ''video and electronics act'' which prohibit Burmese nationals from holding foreign currency or from owning electronic and video equipment without a permit.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/12/world/asia/12myanmar.html?partner=permalink&exprod=permalink | work=The New York Times | title=Prison Terms for Activists in Myanmar | date=12 November 2008 | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> 26 other activists, including five monks from the Ngwe Kyar Yan monastery in Yangon, were given prison sentences ranging from 6 to 24 years.<ref>[http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=14614 40 Burmese Dissidents Given Prison Terms of up to 65 Years] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501121716/http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=14614 |date=1 May 2011 }}</ref> [[U Gambira]] was sentenced to 68 years in prison, at least 12 years of which will be hard labour; other charges against him are still pending.<ref name="AI2">{{cite web|url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/iar/pdf/UGambiraCaseSheet.pdf |title=MYANMAR: Monk Receives 68 Years in Prison |date=3 October 2008 |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |accessdate=20 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429092755/http://www.amnestyusa.org/iar/pdf/UGambiraCaseSheet.pdf |archivedate=29 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Internet control== {{See also|Internet in Myanmar}} The government attempted to block all websites and services that could carry news or information about Myanmar, barring access to web-based email. However protesters were able to access the Internet anyway and as a result the protests received a never before seen level of international news coverage.<ref>[http://fletcher.tufts.edu/forum/archives/pdfs/32-1pdfs/Kyaw.pdf] Challenging the Authoritarian State: Buddhist Monks and Peaceful Protests in Burma. vol.32:1 winter 2008. Retrieved 7 April 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5gpOoMHAX?url=http://fletcher.tufts.edu/forum/archives/pdfs/32-1pdfs/Kyaw.pdf Archived] 16 May 2009.</ref> Bloggers in Yangon succeeded in circumventing the censors, posting pictures and videos on blogs almost as soon as the protests began. Many of these images were picked up by mainstream news organisations, because bloggers had managed to capture images that no one else was able to get. When Aung San Suu Kyi stepped outside her home in Yangon to greet marching monks and supporters on Saturday, the only pictures of the landmark moment were posted on blogs. [[Mizzima News]],<ref>[http://www.mizzima.com/MizzimaNews/News/2007/Sep/92-Sep-2007.html Over 100,000 people in Rangoon and parts of Burma protest] (Third to last paragraph) Mizzima News {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080223100609/http://www.mizzima.com/MizzimaNews/News/2007/Sep/92-Sep-2007.html |date=23 February 2008 }}</ref> an India-based news group run by exiled dissidents, picked up one of the photos of Aung San Suu Kyi and said more than 50,000 people accessed their website that day.<ref>[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5h3-DlPnM6ukmpclQXvMbK3506Rcw Yangon bloggers outsmart Myanmar censors] AFP, 25 September 2007.</ref> Some Burmese internet users are trying to use internet forums to obtain outside information uncontrolled by the government about their situation.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7012984.stm Burma cyber-dissidents crack censorship] BBC, 26 September 2007</ref> On 28 September it was reported that the government had blocked all access to the Internet. The official explanation is that maintenance is being carried out but [[Sky News]] reports that all [[Internet café]]s have also been closed.<ref>[http://www.bangkokpost.com/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=122120 Burma 'cuts all Internet links'] ''Bangkok Post'', 28 September 2007</ref><ref>[http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,30200-1286124,00.html Warning Shots Fired At Protesters] Sky News, 28 September 2007</ref>
By at least midnight local time on 6 October, internet access had been restored to Yangon. {{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} Sources in Burma said on 6 October that the internet seems to be working from 22:00 to 05:00 local time.
==International reactions== {{History of Burma}} {{Main article|International reactions to the Saffron Revolution}} While most countries expressed support for protests and urged the Junta to implement far-reaching reforms, some key countries, such as the People's Republic of China and India maintained commitment to the notion of noninterference and even showed tacit support to the regime.<ref>[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view_article.php?article_id=90622 Faced with Myanmar protests, China reaffirms nonintervention] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011091041/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view_article.php?article_id=90622 |date=11 October 2007 }} Inquirer.net, 25 September 2007.</ref><ref>[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view_article.php?article_id=90444 World urges restraint amid Myanmar protests] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011060259/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view_article.php?article_id=90444 |date=11 October 2007 }} AFP, 25 September 2007.</ref>
===Sanctions=== The United States, European Union, and Canada have imposed a number of sanctions on the junta, including a freeze on bank accounts and restrictions on imports of gems and timber.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7011607.stm personal sanctions] BBC News, 10 October 2007</ref>
The [[United States Department of the Treasury]] announced sanctions against 14 senior officials of Myanmar.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,298298,00.html "Bush Imposes Economic Sanctions on Key Officials From Myanmar's Government"] Fox News Channel</ref> Among those targeted for the sanctions are the junta leader, Senior Gen. [[Than Shwe]], and Deputy Senior Gen. [[Maung Aye]]. The action by Treasury will freeze any assets that the individuals targeted have in US banks or other financial institutions under US jurisdiction. The order also prohibits any US citizens from doing business with the designated individuals.<ref name="monywa">{{cite web|url=http://www.monywa.org/witmone/mizzima_news_singapore30Sept2007.htm|title=Missima News |publisher=monywa.org|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
On 27 September the European Union began considering "targeted reinforced sanctions" against the military junta, with current sanctions already including an arms embargo, asset freezes, and visa and trade bans. Their aim was to back sanctions that did not harm the population.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aLXL8X4IobaI&refer=home Pressure Builds on Myanmar as Protesters Are Shot At (Update)] Bloomberg, 27 September 2007.</ref>
Prime Minister [[John Howard]] of Australia, confirmed reports that the Australian Government would deliver targeted financial sanctions against members of the military junta, as well as possibly introducing other measures to further restrict the military leaders.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/09/27/2045323.htm Howard flags sanctions against Burma] Australian Broadcasting Corporation News, 27 September 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/pm-launches-sanctions-against-junta/2007/09/27/1190486462513.html PM launches sanctions against junta] ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 27 September 2007.</ref>
[[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate [[Desmond Tutu]] urged to intervene in the ongoing protests in Myanmar. "China, you have leverage – tell those brutal men to stop their brutality," Tutu said at the [[Goteborg Book Fair]] in Sweden. Archbishop Emeritus Tutu said that if China did not take a stance against the military rulers in Myanmar he would "join a campaign to boycott the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing Olympics]]" next year.<ref>[http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=148&a=698244 Desmond Tutu vädjar till Burmas ledare] Dagens Nyheter, 28 September 2007.</ref> Calls for a boycott of the 2008 Summer Olympic Games grew around the world, as more people began to say that increased pressure on the Chinese government was the best way to support the Burmese people. The British Broadcasting World News TV service aired interviews, e-mails and text messages from many parts of the world supporting the idea and also called on people to cancel tickets, airline bookings and hotel reservations in Beijing.<ref>http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Protesters-urge-Olympic-boycott-over-Chinese-2538046.php</ref>
===Campaigns=== [[File:Burma Protest London 2007.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Protesters march in London]] Activists and campaign organisations worldwide, including [[Burma Campaign UK]] and the [[US Campaign for Burma]] along with members of the Support the Monks' Protest in Burma Facebook group (later the [[Burma Global Action Network]]), called for 6 October to be designated a [[Global Day of Action for Burma]] from 12:00 noon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burmacampaign.org.uk/demonstrations.html|title=Global Day of Action for Burma| accessdate= 10 April 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090309093004/http://www.burmacampaign.org.uk/demonstrations.html| archivedate=9 March 2009| deadurl= no}}</ref> This event was also held in Sydney (Australia), [[Montreal]], Ottawa, [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]] and [[Vancouver]] (Canada); New York, Washington D.C., San Diego (United States); [[Dublin]] (Ireland),<ref name="BreakingNews.ie">[http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/mhmhausneykf/ Protest demands end to Burmese military rule] BreakingNews.ie</ref> Hong Kong and Norway in their consecutive days.
[[File:Burma protest in Kitchener, Ontario.jpg|thumb|Protesters march in [[Kitchener, Ontario]]]] [[File:Free Myanmar by Latuff2.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Cartoon by [[Carlos Latuff]]]]
International Bloggers' Day for Burma, a campaign for bloggers to not post to their blogs, was to be on 4 October. Instead they are being asked to put up a banner, underlined with the words ''Free Burma!''.<ref>[http://www2.free-burma.org/index.php#attend International Bloggers' Day for Burma on 4 October] Free Burma!</ref>
A worldwide action by bloggers originating in Italy will set a signpost for peace and support the people of Myanmar through the internet. On 4 October 2007 all bloggers and website owners worldwide were called upon to support the "free Burma" campaign by adding a graphic to their website frontdoors and blog only about Myanmar related topics. An internet action likewise has not been reported so far.<ref name="dariosalvelli">{{cite web|url=http://www.dariosalvelli.com/2007/09/appello-per-la-birmania-stop-blogging-for-birmania |title=Appello per la Birmania: STOP Blogging for Birmania | Dario Salvelli's Blog |publisher=dariosalvelli.com|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
A Facebook users group, "Support the Monks' protest in Burma", was formed immediately following the first network reports of monks marching past Aung San Suu Kyi's house. The group grew to over 380,000 members by 9 October and 440,000 at its peak. Some members of the group, who later formed into an official organisation called [[Burma Global Action Network]] joined the call for a [[Global Day of Action for Burma]] through public demonstrations on 6 October in cities and towns worldwide. [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] magazine noted the significance of the grassroots effort in an article asking whether Facebook has given birth to 'open-source politics.'<ref name="wired">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/politics/onlinerights/news/2007/10/myanmarfacebook |title='Open-Source Politics' Taps Facebook for Myanmar Protests|publisher=wired.com|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
A campaign labelled "[[Panties for Peace]]" began on 16 October; focussing on the superstitions of Burma's generals, particularly junta chief Than Shwe, that views contact with any item of women's wear as depriving them of their power, women throughout the world have been sending packages to Burmese embassies containing panties; the campaign has spread to Australia, Europe, Singapore and Thailand. People in Burma also began to hang pictures of Than Shwe around the necks of stray dogs, as it is a very strong insult in Burmese tradition to be associated with a dog, and began to spray anti-junta graffiti in bus and train stations, with slogans such as "killer Than Shwe".<ref>[http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=9048 "Panties for Peace" Campaign Wins Wide Support] ''The Irrawady'' 18 October 2007</ref>
In Australia, [[James Mathison]] from [[Australian Idol]] has lent his support, hosting a Free Burma rally on [http://www.aucampaignforburma.org/UpcomingEvents.htm 10 November] in Sydney.
While local protests at French oil giant [[Total Oil]]'s garages were taking place from October on,<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/topic.php?uid=24957770200&topic=3131 "Protest at Total Oil garages" discussion at Facebook]</ref><ref name="totaloutofburma">{{cite web|url=http://totaloutofburma.blogspot.com |title=Total out of Burma |publisher=totaloutofburma.blogspot.com|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> the first global consumers' boycott of [[Total Oil]] (which also owns ELF and FINA) and US-based [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] (which also owns [[Texaco]], [[Caltex]] and [[Unocal]]) was called for on 16 November 2007 because the corporations to be able to exploit [[Yadana Project|Yadana natural gas pipeline]] in southern [[Burma]] are paying to the junta an estimated $450million/year and are now lobbying in the US and Europe against government measures to support a democratic transition in Burma. To protect Total's interests, the government has become an obstacle to any serious strengthening of EU measures against [[Burma]]. The French government has pushed for the junta to be admitted into international associations, defending Total's investments. The global online initiative hosted by [[Avaaz.org]] "to refuse to buy fuel from any Total, Chevron, ELF, FINA, Texaco or Caltex station in our home countries and wherever we travel" was signed by 20,255 people with the aim of delivering 40,000 signatures to the top management of the corporations.
Although [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] and [[Total Oil]] claim that their presence benefits the Burmese population, [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] said in [[Le Monde]] that "Total has become the main supporter of the Burmese military regime." already in 2005.<ref name="soros">{{cite web|url=http://www.soros.org/initiatives/bpsai/articles_publications/publications/totalbcuk_2005/total_report.pdf |title=Open Society Foundations (OSF) | "TOTALitarian Oil" Report, The Burma Campaign UK, 2005, PDF |publisher=soros.org|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox United States federal proposed legislation | name = Sandia Pueblo Settlement Technical Amendment Act | fullname = To make a technical amendment to the T’uf Shur Bien Preservation Trust Area Act, and for other purposes. | acronym = | nickname = | introduced in the = 113th | sponsored by = [[Tom Udall|Sen. Tom Udall (D, NM)]] | number of co-sponsors = 1 | public law url = | cite public law = {{USPL|113|119}} | cite statutes at large = | acts affected = [[T’uf Shur Bien Preservation Trust Area Act]] | acts repealed = | title affected = | sections created = | sections affected = {{USC|16|539m–11}} | agenciesaffected = [[United States Department of the Interior]] | authorizationsofappropriations = | appropriations = | leghisturl = | introducedin = Senate | introducedbill = {{USBill|113|s|611}} | introducedby = [[Tom Udall|Sen. Tom Udall (D, NM)]] | introduceddate = March 19, 2013 | committees = [[United States Senate Committee on Indian Affairs]] | passedbody1 = Senate | passeddate1 = March 12, 2014 | passedvote1 = [[unanimous consent]] | passedbody2 = House | passedas2 = | passeddate2 = May 28, 2014 | passedvote2 = [[voice vote]] | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = | agreeddate3 = | agreedvote3 = | agreedbody4 = | agreeddate4 = | agreedvote4 = | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | signedpresident = | signeddate = | unsignedpresident = | unsigneddate = | vetoedpresident = | vetoeddate = | overriddenbody1 = | overriddendate1 = | overriddenvote1 = | overriddenbody2 = | overriddendate2 = | overriddenvote2 = | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }}
The '''Sandia Pueblo Settlement Technical Amendment Act''' ({{USBill|113|s|611}}; {{USPL|113|119}}) is a bill that would transfer to the [[Sandia Pueblo]] of [[New Mexico]] some land from the [[United States Forest Service]], provided that land remains an "open space in its natural state."<ref name="611sum"/><ref name="611cbo"/><ref name="CoxSenatePass"/> The bill is a technical corrections bill and is supposed to transfer 700 acres from the federal government to the Sandia Pueblo.<ref name=TulalipNews>{{cite news|title=Chairwoman Cantwell Holds Hearing on Tribal Resources Legislation|url=http://www.tulalipnews.com/wp/2013/05/10/chairwoman-cantwell-holds-hearing-on-tribal-resources-legislation/|accessdate=14 March 2014|newspaper=Tulalip News|date=10 May 2013}}</ref>
The bill passed in the [[United States Senate]] during the [[113th United States Congress]].<ref name="CoxSenatePass"/>
==Background== {{main|Sandia Pueblo}}
Sandia Pueblo {{IPAc-en|s|æ|n|ˈ|d|iː|ə}} is a [[federally recognized tribe]] of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] [[Pueblo people]] inhabiting a {{convert|101.114|km2|mi2|adj=on}} [[Indian reservation|reservation]] of the same name in the eastern [[Rio Grande Rift]] of central New Mexico. It is bounded by the city of [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]] to the south and by the foothills of the [[Sandia Mountains]], a landform the people hold sacred and which was central to the traditional economy and remains important in the spiritual life of the community, to the east. A forested area known as the ''bosque'' surrounds the rest of the reservation, and serves as a source of firewood and wild game. A resident population of 4,414 was reported as of the [[United States Census, 2000|2000 census]]. Two communities located on its territory are [[Pueblo of Sandia Village, New Mexico|Pueblo of Sandia Village]] and part (population 3,235) of the town of [[Bernalillo, New Mexico|Bernalillo]]. A federally [[Native American recognition in the United States|recognized]] tribe, Sandia Pueblo is one of 19 of New Mexico's Native American [[pueblo]]s. The land that would be conveyed to the Sandia Pueblo is considered to have important spiritual and cultural meaning to the tribe.<ref name="TulalipNews"/>
==Provisions of the bill== ''This summary is based largely on the summary provided by the [[Congressional Research Service]], a [[public domain]] source.''<ref name=611sum>{{cite web|title=S. 611 - Summary|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-bill/611|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref>
The Sandia Pueblo Settlement Technical Amendment Act would amend the [[T'uf Shur Bien Preservation Trust Area Act]] to require the [[United States Department of Agriculture|Secretary of Agriculture]], upon the receipt of certain consideration and at the request of the Sandia Pueblo of New Mexico and the [[United States Department of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]], to transfer certain National Forest land to the Secretary of the Interior to be held in trust for the Pueblo, provided a land exchange with the Pueblo required by that Act is not completed within 90 days of this Act's enactment.<ref name="611sum"/>
The bill would require that National Forest land to be preserved as open space in its natural state.<ref name="611sum"/>
The bill would also require the Pueblo to transfer to the Secretary, in exchange for such land, the Pueblo's La Luz tract and an amount equal to the difference between the value of: (1) the National Forest land as open space in its natural state, and (2) the La Luz tract and the compensation owed to the Pueblo by the Secretary for the right-of-way and conservation easement on its Piedra Lisa tract.<ref name="611sum"/>
==Congressional Budget Office report== ''This summary is based largely on the summary provided by the [[Congressional Budget Office]], as ordered reported by the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs on October 30, 2013. This is a [[public domain]] source.''<ref name=611cbo>{{cite web|title=S. 611 - CBO|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/45173|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref>
S. 611 would require the Secretary of Agriculture to transfer certain lands in the [[Sandia Mountain Wilderness]] and [[Cibola National Forest]] in New Mexico to the [[United States Department of the Interior]] to be held in trust for the Pueblo of Sandia. In exchange for the specified National Forest lands, the legislation would require the Secretary of the Interior to transfer certain lands and easements held in trust for the Pueblo of Sandia to the Forest Service.<ref name="611cbo"/>
The [[Congressional Budget Office]] (CBO) estimates that implementing S. 611 would have no significant impact on the federal budget. Based on information provided by the Forest Service, CBO estimates that the cost of administering the land transfers would be minimal. Enacting S. 611 would not affect direct spending or revenues; therefore, [[PAYGO|pay-as-you-go]] procedures do not apply.<ref name="611cbo"/>
S. 611 contains no intergovernmental or private-sector mandates as defined in the [[Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995|Unfunded Mandates Reform Act]] and would benefit the Pueblo of Sandia.<ref name="611cbo"/>
==Procedural history== The Sandia Pueblo Settlement Technical Amendment Act was introduced into the [[United States Senate]] on March 19, 2013 by [[Tom Udall|Sen. Tom Udall (D, NM)]].<ref name=611allactions>{{cite web|title=S. 611 - All Actions|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-bill/611/all-actions/|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> It was referred to the [[United States Senate Committee on Indian Affairs]]. It was reported on January 28, 2014 alongside [http://beta.congress.gov/113/crpt/srpt136/CRPT-113srpt136.pdf Senate Report 113-136].<ref name="611allactions"/> The bill passed in the Senate on March 12, 2014 by [[unanimous consent]].<ref name=CoxSenatePass>{{cite news|last=Cox|first=Ramsey|title=Senate passes bill giving Pueblo Indians forest land|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/200638-senate-passes-bill-giving-pueblo-indians-forest-land|accessdate=14 March 2014|newspaper=The Hill|date=12 March 2014}}</ref> On May 28, 2014, the [[United States House of Representatives]] voted to pass the bill in a [[voice vote]]. On June 9, 2014, President [[Barack Obama]] signed the bill into law, becoming {{USPL|113|119}}.<ref name="611allactions"/>
==See also== *[[List of bills in the 113th United States Congress]]

{{italic title}} The '''1994 reenactments of the Lincoln–Douglas Debates''' took place between August 20 and October 15, 1994 and were facilitated and aired by [[C-SPAN]]. They featured [[historical reenactors]] presenting, in their entireties, the [[Lincoln–Douglas debates|series of seven debates]] between [[Abraham Lincoln]] and [[Stephen A. Douglas]] that took place during the [[United States Senate elections, 1858|1858 U.S. Senate campaign]] in [[Illinois]]. The debate reenactments were held in the same seven cities as were the 1858 debates, and were performed on dates very close to the anniversaries of the original debates.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-07-03/travel/9407030070_1_lincoln-douglas-debates-senate-debates-c-span-spokeswoman|title=Towns To Star In C-span's Historical Debate Re-enactments|publisher=}} They were broadcast live on C-SPAN, and have been rebroadcast periodically ever since. ==Background== The inspiration for the series came from the book ''The Lincoln–Douglas Debates: The First Complete, Unexpurgated Text'', edited by [[Harold Holzer]]. Holzer had been interviewed about that book the previous year on the C-SPAN series ''[[Booknotes]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/OttawaD|title=Lincoln Douglas Ottawa Debate Preview, Aug 20 1994 - Video - C-SPAN.org|website=C-SPAN.org}} In 1993, C-SPAN staff approached the mayors of the seven cities in Illinois where the 1858 debates had been held ([[Ottawa, Illinois|Ottawa]], [[Freeport, Illinois|Freeport]], [[Jonesboro, Illinois|Jonesboro]], [[Charleston, Illinois|Charleston]], [[Galesburg, Illinois|Galesburg]], [[Quincy, Illinois|Quincy]], and [[Alton, Illinois|Alton]]) and arranged with each city to recreate the debates using their own local resources. Subsequently, C-SPAN spent over $300,000 on the promotion and coverage of the debates and on the creation of related educational materials.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1994-08-20/features/1994232090_1_lincoln-douglas-debates-c-span-debates-history|title=C-Span, Illinois re-enact Lincoln-Douglas debates History in the Re-making|publisher=}} The [[C-SPAN School Bus]] was used as a traveling television studio at each of the debate locations. Prof. [[John Splaine]] of the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], was a consultant to C-SPAN and provided commentary on each of the debates. ==Debates== {|border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=5 class="wikitable sortable" ! width="120"|Original air date

{{redirect|TUSC|the auto racing series|TUDOR United SportsCar Championship}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Use British English|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox political party |name=Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition |logo=[[File:TUSC transparency.png|250px]] |caption=TUSC logo |colorcode=#EC008C |abbreviation=TUSC |leader=[[Dave Nellist]]{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/the_daily_politics/8637620.stm|title=Dave Nellist on the Trade Unionist & Socialist Coalition|author=|date=22 April 2010|work=Daily Politics|publisher=BBC}} |founded=2010 |ideology=[[Trade unionism]]
[[Socialism]]
[[Euroscepticism]] |position=[[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] to [[Far-left politics|far-left]] |european= |international= |europarl= |colors={{Color box|#ec008c|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|#7e1416|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|#ed1d25|border=darkgray}}
Pink, brown and red |blank1_title=Members |blank1=[[Socialist Party (England and Wales)|Socialist Party]]
[[Socialist Party Scotland]]
[[Solidarity (Scotland)|Solidarity]]
[[Socialist Workers Party (UK)|Socialist Workers Party]] |seats1_title=[[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] |seats1={{Composition bar|0|650|hex=#EC008C}} |seats2_title=[[House of Lords]] |seats2={{Composition bar|0|809|hex=#EC008C}} |seats3_title=[[European Parliament]] |seats3={{Composition bar|0|73|hex=#EC008C}} |seats4_title=[[Local government in the United Kingdom|Local government]] |seats4={{Composition bar|0|21871|hex=#EC008C}} |website=[http://www.tusc.org.uk/ www.tusc.org.uk] |country=United Kingdom}} '''Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition''' (TUSC) is a [[socialism|socialist]] [[electoral alliance]] launched in Britain for the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2015-32254035 'Election 2015: TUSC launches '100% anti-austerity' manifesto'].
'They are members and supporters of the Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition (TUSC); a left-wing political group standing candidates across the UK at the general election'.
BBC News. Published 10 April 2015. Retrieved 27 March 2016.[https://www.rt.com/uk/248641-tusc-socialist-election-manifesto/ ‘TUSC is 100% anti-austerity’: Socialists launch election manifesto in heart of UK capitalism]
'The left-wing organization is fielding candidates in more than 130 parliamentary seats and over 600 council seats across the country in May’s general election'.
RT [online]. Published 10 April 2015. Retrieved 2 April 2016.{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Lucy|title=Revealed: Labour's hard-left infiltrators|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/politics/article4519890.ece|accessdate=25 March 2016|work=The Times|subscription=y|date=7 August 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Silvera|first1=Ian|title=Far-left TUSC seeks anti-austerity electoral pact with Jeremy Corbyn's Labour|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/far-left-tusc-seeks-anti-austerity-electoral-pact-jeremy-corbyns-labour-1519615|accessdate=25 March 2016|work=International Business Times|date=14 September 2015}} TUSC's co-founder was the [[National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers|RMT]] union general secretary [[Bob Crow]]. Members of the [[Public and Commercial Services Union|PCS]], [[National Union of Teachers|NUT]], [[Fire Brigades Union|FBU]] and [[POA (trade union)|POA]] unions are on the steering committee. The most prominent participating groups are the [[Socialist Party (England and Wales)|Socialist Party]] and [[Solidarity (Scotland)|Solidarity]]. At the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], TUSC stood 135 parliamentary candidates across England, Wales and Scotland,{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/txt/336.pdf |title=TUSC Prospective Parliamentary Candidates for 2015.}} and 619 in the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2015|local elections]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/txt/337.pdf |title=TUSC Council Candidates for 2015.}} TUSC did not stand candidates in the [[2017 United Kingdom general election|2017 UK general election]] as they supported [[Jeremy Corbyn]], leader of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]. ==Foundation: No2EU == At the March 2009 Socialist Party congress, RMT executive members Alex Gordon and Brian Denny addressed Socialist Party delegates in an official capacity, outlining the RMT's proposal for workers slates in the European elections in June. At a later congress session this initiative was formally agreed by congress delegates, and [[No to EU – Yes to Democracy]] (NO2EU) was formed.{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/issue/571/7050|title=Socialist Party congress reports|publisher=Socialist Party |date=19 March 2009|accessdate=2014-05-02}} NO2EU, an electoral alliance, headed by Bob Crow, between the RMT, the [[Communist Party of Britain]] and the Socialist Party, subsequently led to the formation of the Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition. The Socialist Party, which had previously participated in the [[Socialist Alliance (England)|Socialist Alliance]] and [[Welsh Socialist Alliance]] and backed the [[Campaign for a New Workers' Party]], termed No2EU "an important first step towards independent [[working class]] political representation", despite criticisms of the name and other minor issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/articles/8323|title=Action needed to bring election coalition into shape|publisher=Socialist Party |date=3 November 2009|accessdate=2014-05-02}} The Socialist Party stated it "would prefer a name that includes 'socialism', for marked ideological contrast to New Labour, and also one that makes it clear that the coalition is a working class alternative." Nevertheless, the Socialist Party noted the success of [[The Left (Germany)|Die Linke]] in Germany, the [[New Anticapitalist Party]] in France and [[Coalition of the Radical Left]] in Greece, and emphasized the need for a "genuine socialist alternative" in the European elections.{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/international/Europe/France/7413 |title=Europe |publisher=Socialist Party |date=2009-06-09 |accessdate=2013-12-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/international/Europe/France/7590 |title=Europe |publisher=Socialist Party |date=2009-07-29 |accessdate=2013-12-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/print/4009 |title=Rising class struggles across Europe |publisher=Socialistparty.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-12-29}} After the European elections, in July 2009, the CPB released a statement{{cite web|url=http://www.communist-party.org.uk/ec-110709.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=16 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605060927/http://www.communist-party.org.uk/ec-110709.pdf |archivedate=5 June 2011 }} expressing willingness to continue the No2EU programme and support left-wing alliance candidates in some constituencies, but also called for a vote for Labour Party candidates in others. However, on 17 January 2010 the Executive Committee of the Communist Party declined to formally participate in the coalition.{{cite web|url=http://www.communist-party.org.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=712:executive-committee-statement-on-elections&catid=69:executive-committee&Itemid=77 |title=Executive Committee statement on elections |publisher=Communist-party.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-12-29}} Negotiations to found the coalition continued over several months after the EU election. One proposed name for the coalition was "Trade Unionists and Green Socialists Alliance".{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/keyword/Capitalism/British_politics/8323/03-11-2009/action-needed-to-bring-election-coalition-into-shape |title=Capitalism :: British politics |publisher=Socialist Party |date=2009-11-03 |accessdate=2013-12-29}} The RMT, which had formally supported No2EU, initially decided, in January 2010, not to similarly back TUSC, but allowed individual branches to support it.Clive Heemskerk, "[http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/issue/610/8762 Trade unionist and socialist coalition]", ''The Socialist'', 3 February 2010 It later gave TUSC candidates its full backing (see below). On 12 January 2010, the coalition was announced{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/articles/8673 |title=Launch of Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition |publisher=Socialist Party |date= |accessdate=2013-12-29}} and subsequently, the RMT National Council of Executives supported 20 TUSC candidates on receipt of local RMT branch requests.{{cite web|title=Becoming a TUSC candidate|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/candidates.php|website=TUSC|accessdate=25 March 2016}} TUSC chairperson [[Dave Nellist]] stood as a candidate for the coalition in the constituency of [[Coventry North East]]. Among the other candidates were Jackie Grunsell in Colne Valley constituency, Keith Gibson in Hull West and Hessle, [[Dave Hill (Professor)|Dave Hill]] in Brighton Kemptown, Ian Page in Lewisham Deptford, Rob Williams in Swansea West and Tim Cutter in Southampton Itchen. Some political groups such as the [[Alliance for Workers Liberty]] and the ''[[Weekly Worker]]'' newspaper have argued that the coalition was formed in secret and without democratic input.{{cite web|url=http://www.workersliberty.org/story/2010/01/15/son-no2eu-goes-public-tusc |title="Son of No2EU" goes public as "TUSC" |publisher=Workers' Liberty |date= |accessdate=2013-12-29}} Meanwhile, just after the 2009 European Elections, the [[Socialist Workers Party (UK)|Socialist Workers Party]], which had not taken part in No2EU but which had itself been part of the Socialist Alliance and the [[Respect Party]], published its "Open Letter to the Left",{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=18114 |title=Open letter: Left must unite to create an alternative |publisher=Socialistworker.co.uk |date=2009-06-09 |accessdate=2013-12-29}} in which it called for "a united fightback to save jobs and services" and subsequently joined TUSC; it left TUSC (England and wales) in 2017 but remains part of the autonomous Scottish TUSC.{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/articles/25022 |title=TUSC: SWP suspends participation in England/Wales |publisher=Socialist Party |date=2017-03-15 |accessdate=2018-04-07}} ==Trade Union interaction== ===Trade Union endorsement=== Three Annual General Meetings (2012, 2013 and 2014) of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT) have endorsed RMT support for TUSC candidates and the RMT is formally represented on the TUSC steering committee. TUSC has been endorsed by the late [[Bob Crow]], formerly the General Secretary of the RMT, Brian Caton, former General Secretary of the [[POA (trade union)|Prison Officers' Association]] (POA), Steve Gillan and Joe Simpson, General Secretary and Assistant General Secretary of the POA, Janice Godrich, President of the [[Public and Commercial Services Union]] (PCS), Chris Baugh, Assistant General Secretary of the PCS and eight members of the [[UNISON]] National Executive Council. ===Criticism from the Unite union=== In February 2015, senior figures from [[Unite the Union]] condemned the Socialist Party and by implication TUSC, for standing candidates against Labour in marginal constituencies for the 2015 general election. The open letter addressed to the Socialist Party, which does not mention TUSC, accuses the Socialist Party of having a "derisory" electoral record.{{cite web|url=http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-b3ce-Unites-left-urges-Tusc-to-reconsider |title=Unite’s left urges Tusc to reconsider |publisher=Morning Star |date=2015-02-27 |accessdate=2015-03-01}} In response, the Socialist Party claimed that a Labour government "would be at best austerity-lite and a continuation of the crisis that faces working class people."{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/articles/20185|title=Discussion in Unite 'United Left' on stance in general election|publisher=Socialist Party|date=2015-02-26 |accessdate=2015-04-17}} ==Alleged TUSC infiltration of the Labour Party in 2015== In July 2015, Labour MP [[Steve Reed (politician)|Steve Reed]] accused TUSC members in his [[Croydon North (UK Parliament constituency)|Croydon North]] constituency, including a TUSC candidate who had stood against Labour in the May 2015 general election, of joining the Labour Party in order to vote for [[Jeremy Corbyn]] in the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2015|Labour leadership election]]. According to Reed: "The system was set up for Labour supporters, not Labour opponents. We don’t know if this is a one-off or a systemic attempt by [[Trotskyism|Trotskyites]] to infiltrate the Labour Party."{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/labour-chiefs-under-growing-pressure-6172491|title=Labour chiefs under growing pressure to weed out hard-Left from infiltrating the party|publisher=Daily Mirror|date=2015-07-31 |accessdate=2015-08-01}} In an interview for ''[[The Independent]]'', Socialist Party deputy leader [[Hannah Sell]] stated that "a Corbyn victory would create the basis for a new 100 per cent anti-austerity party of the working class."{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/labour-leadership-jeremy-corbyn-win-would-effectively-form-new-party-says-socialist-group-10419988.html|title=Labour leadership: Jeremy Corbyn win would effectively 'form new party', says socialist group|publisher=The Independent|date=2015-07-27 |accessdate=2015-08-01|location=London|first=James|last=Cusick}} As of early August 2015, 92 TUSC members, including 11 TUSC candidates who stood in the 2015 general election, are known to have become registered supporters of the Labour Party.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/politics/article4519890.ece|title=Revealed: Labour’s hard-left infiltrators|publisher=The Times|date=2015-08-07 |accessdate=2015-08-07}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/aug/07/labour-leadership-election-260-former-candidates-and-members-rival-parties-apply-vote|title=Labour leadership election: 260 members of rival parties ask to vote|publisher=The Guardian|date=2015-08-07 |accessdate=2015-08-07}} ==Policies== TUSC is a political party with a federal structure, not a coalition. It has been registered as a political party with the Electoral Commission since 2010. All candidates supporting the coalition must support a core policy platform, but beyond this each candidate is free to campaign on the platform of their own political party. TUSC launched its manifesto for the 2015 general election in London's financial district of Canary Wharf.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2015-32253527|title=BBC News: TUSC manifesto launch: 'Only 100% anti-austerity party'}} The TUSC registered with the Electoral Commission to campaign in favour of Britain leaving the European Union. === Five key pledges === The manifesto outlines "five key pledges":{{cite web|url=http://tusc2015.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/2015-press-pack.pdf|title=Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition 2015 Press Pack}} * End cuts and austerity. For a democratic socialist society run in the interests of the millions not the billionaires. * Trade union rights to fight low pay. £10.12 an hour minimum wage now, scrap zero hour contracts. * A mass council home building programme and immediate introduction of rent controls. * Scrap student fees. Free education as a right for all. * For democratic public ownership of the National Health Service, railways, public services, utilities and banks. === Local election platform === TUSC local election candidates sign up to a platform, which commits them to: * Oppose all cuts to council jobs, services, pay and conditions. We reject the claim that ‘some cuts’ are necessary to our services or that the national debt is a reason for austerity. * Refuse to implement the [[Welfare Reform Act 2012|Bedroom Tax]] now. Councils should write off all bedroom tax-related arrears, withdraw all court proceedings and eviction orders where the bedroom tax has been a factor, and call on Housing Associations to do the same. * Support all workers’ struggles against the cuts, privatisation and government policies making ordinary people pay for the crisis caused by the bankers and the bosses. Defend the national collective bargaining arrangements for council workers. * Reject increases in council tax, rent and service charges to compensate for government cuts. * Vote against the privatisation of council jobs and services, or the transfer of council services to ‘social enterprises’ or ‘arms-length’ management organisations, which are first steps to privatisation. * Oppose racism and fascism and stand up for equality for all. * Campaign for the introduction of a [[Living Wage]] above the minimum wage, including for council employees and those working for council contractors. * Use all the legal powers available to councils to oppose both the cuts and government policies which centrally impose the transfer of public services to private bodies. This includes using councils’ powers to refer local NHS decisions, initiate referenda and organise public commissions and consultations in campaigns to defend public services. * Vote for councils to refuse to implement the cuts. We will support councils which in the first instance use their reserves and prudential borrowing powers to avoid making cuts. But we argue that the best way to mobilise the mass campaign that is necessary to defeat the dismantling of council services is to set a budget that meets the needs of the local community and demands that government funding makes up the shortfall. * Support action against climate change and for a future where sustainability comes before profit. == Elections == === General elections === ==== Summary of general election performance ==== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! No. of candidates !! Total votes !! Average votes per candidate !! % of vote !! Change (% points) !![[Deposit (politics)|Saved deposits]]'''*''' !! No. of MPs !! Rank |- style="text-align:center;" ! style="text-align:left;"| [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010]] || 44 || 15,573 || 354 || 0.1 || || || 0 || |- style="text-align:center;" ! style="text-align:left;"| [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015]] || 126 || 36,327 || 284 || 0.1 || || || 0 || |} ==== 2010 general election ==== TUSC and the Scottish TUSC (STUSC) announced 44 parliamentary candidates for the 2010 general election, including ten in Scotland.{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/candidates2010.php|title=Candidates for TUSC |work=TUSC |date= |accessdate=2013-12-29}} They received a total of 15,573 votes, or 0.1% of the popular vote. TUSC's average vote nationwide was around 371 (1.0%); no deposits were returned. TUSC was registered with the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] in January 2010.{{cite web|url=http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/English/Registrations/PP804|title=Electoral Commission: Register of Political Parties|work=Electoral Commission}} TUSC claimed that the possibilities of electoral success should not be exaggerated. TUSC consistently stated that "not too much can be drawn from a handful of electoral contests, either ‘writing off’ TUSC or exaggerating the possibilities at this stage."{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/press011212.php|title=November by-elections|publisher=TUSC|date=1 December 2012}} Another claimed factor in 2010 was a perceived "squeeze"{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=21185|title=Britain's general election: no winner and no mandate|publisher=Socialist Worker|date=6 May 2010}} that generated disappointing results for many smaller parties. "Fear of a Tory government galvanised people to vote Labour, and we were squeezed. People were too afraid to demand something better for fear of getting something worse." Tottenham candidate Jenny Sutton claimed.{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=21188|title=The left in the election: good campaigns but TUSC vote squeezed|publisher=Socialist Worker|date=11 May 2010}} ==== 2015 general election ==== [[File:2015 TUSC Candidates.svg|thumb|Map of the constituencies TUSC contested in the 2015 general election.]] TUSC stood 135 prospective parliamentary candidates across England, Wales and Scotland, as well as 619 council candidates in local elections. The organisation announced in October 2014 that it had received a guarantee of funding from [[Socialist Alliance (England)|Socialist Alliance]].{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistalliance.org.uk/?linkId=1&storyId=124|accessdate=2014-12-13 |title=Socialist Alliance agrees to use large part of recent legacy to help fund largest possible left electoral challenge – through TUSC |publisher=socialistalliance.org.uk}} The funds would provide for one hundred deposits in parliamentary contests, as well as a Party Political Broadcast.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pcEMrCTVRdg|title=Vote TUSC against CUTS – TUSC election broadcast|author=|date=17 April 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}} The party performed badly at the election, winning 36,327 votes, or 0.1% of the popular vote. No parliamentary seats were gained and no deposits were saved.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election/2015/results | work=BBC News | title=Results of the 2015 General Election – Election 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/jul/26/jeremy-corbyn-genuine-labour-supporters-leadership-election|title=Jeremy Corbyn: I only want genuine Labour supporters to vote for me|author=Patrick Wintour|date=|work=the Guardian}} ===General election, 2017=== TUSC called for a victory for Labour in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election]] and did not run candidates in the elections.{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/17366/11-05-2017/tusc-confirms-no-candidates-in-june-and-full-support-for-a-corbyn-led-government-with-socialist-policies |title=Tusc Confirms No Candidates In June And Full Support For A Corbyn Led Government With Socialist Policies |publisher=Tusc.org.uk |date=2017-05-11 |accessdate=2018-04-07}} === Local elections === ==== 2018 local elections ==== Following the 2018 elections, TUSC retained at least one affiliated councillor in Coxford, Southampton, following the re-election (as Independent - Putting People First) of TUSC national steering committee member Keith Morrell.http://www.tusc.org.uk/txt/424.pdf Two other former Putting People First councillors also retain their seats as Independents, but the group has since dissolved.https://www.dailyecho.co.uk/news/16301861.independent-group-on-city-council-to-split/ ==== 2016 local elections ==== Following the 2016 elections, TUSC had three councillors in Southampton under the banner of Coxford Putting People First, {{cite web|url=https://sotontusc.wordpress.com/2016/05/12/third-anti-cuts-councillor-elected-in-coxford-congratulations-tammy-thomas/ |title=Third anti-cuts councillor elected in Coxford! Congratulations Tammy Thomas! |publisher=Southampton TUSC |date=2016-05-12 |accessdate=2018-04-07}} Kevin Bennett having lost his seat in Warrington;{{cite web |url=https://www.warrington.gov.uk/info/201106/voting_and_elections/2235/borough_council_election_results_may_2016 |title=Borough council election results, May 2016 |publisher=Warrington Borough Council |date= |accessdate=2018-04-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604161959/https://www.warrington.gov.uk/info/201106/voting_and_elections/2235/borough_council_election_results_may_2016 |archivedate=4 June 2016 |df=dmy-all }} Hull Red Labour and Walsall Democratic Labour also lost their remaining seats. ==== 2015 local elections ==== TUSC renewed its promise to field the largest left-of-Labour challenge in the parliamentary and local authority elections. It bolstered its 2014 local election candidacy count by 70, bringing the total to 650. As it also fielded 135 PPCs, in every major town and city in England, Wales, and Scotland, TUSC subsequently exceeded the overall number of candidates to satisfy the BBC's fair coverage threshold, qualifying it for distribution of election material via the Royal Mail, as well as time on the major networks for the airing of a Party Election Broadcast.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AseACpjSMc0|title=Dave Nellist on RT|author=|date=26 March 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}} TUSC gained no seats (and, in one ward, no votes) and lost three anti-cuts councillors in Leicester and Hull. They retain one affiliated councillor each in Warrington, Walsall and Hull, and two in Southampton.{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/17091/08-05-2015/results-still-coming-in-but-tusc-set-to-poll-100000-votes-for-bold-no-cuts-message|title=RESULTS STILL COMING IN BUT TUSC SET TO POLL 100000 VOTES FOR BOLD NO CUTS MESSAGE|author=|date=|work=tusc.org.uk}} ==== 2014 local elections ==== TUSC announced the 'biggest left-of-Labour electoral challenge in 60 years' in the 2014 local elections, fielding 561 candidates.{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/16966/26-04-2014/tusc-announces-biggest-left-of-labour-electoral-challenge-in-sixty-years|title=TUSC announces 'biggest left-of-Labour electoral challenge in sixty years'|publisher=TUSC|accessdate=2 May 2014}} There were 53 candidates who were members of the RMT transport workers' union, 19 Communication Workers' Union members who were candidates, 18 members of the National Union of Teachers, 16 PCS members, 20 members of the University and College Union. From the big Labour-affiliated unions, there were 74 Unison members standing for TUSC and 130 members of Unite. TUSC gained two seats in Southampton with the defection of Don Thomas from Labour and the re-election of Keith Morrell, also previously Labour, as Councillors Against Cuts,{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/16998/23-05-2014/local-elections-2014-great-victory-as-tusc-rebel-councillor-re-elected|title=LOCAL ELECTIONS 2014 GREAT VICTORY AS TUSC REBEL COUNCILLOR RE ELECTED|author=|date=|work=tusc.org.uk}} as well as a second seat on Maltby Town Council. The overall popular votes achieved in the campaign exceeded 68,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/16920/28-02-2014/second-maltby-councillor-for-tusc|title=SECOND MALTBY COUNCILLOR FOR TUSC|author=|date=|work=tusc.org.uk}} TUSC lost its representation in Maltby in the autumn of 2014 with the removal of their two councillors for non-attendance,{{cite web|url=http://www.rotherhamadvertiser.co.uk/news/97135/angry-at-maltby-council-decision.aspx|title=- Angry at Maltby council decision|author=|date=|work=Rotherham Advertiser}} and lost its Preston councillor when Michael Lavalette retired his seat.{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/16982/12-05-2014/socialist-councillors-can-help-boost-resistance|title=SOCIALIST COUNCILLORS CAN HELP BOOST RESISTANCE|author=|date=|work=tusc.org.uk}} However, TUSC gained two affiliated councillors in the shape of Hull Red Labour, following their expulsion from Labour in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/campaign/Election_campaigns/TUSC/20210|title=TUSC|author=|date=|work=Socialist Party}} In January 2015, TUSC gained a councillor in Warrington (Fairfield and Howley ward) with the defection of Kevin Bennett from Labour.{{cite web|url=http://cmis.warrington.gov.uk/cmis5/Councillors/tabid/62/ctl/ViewCMIS_Person/mid/480/id/445/ScreenMode/Ward/Default.aspx|title=Councillors|author=|date=|work=warrington.gov.uk}} ==== 2013 local and by-elections ==== A total of 120 candidates contested the English local elections on 2 May under the TUSC umbrella, 5% of the seats. In addition, TUSC stood a candidate in the Doncaster mayoral contest and two candidates in council by-elections that were held on the same day. It was mainly county councils up for election, largely Conservative controlled. The TUSC candidate for the mayor of Doncaster, Mary Jackson, polled 1,916 votes, achieving sixth place, ahead of the Liberal Democrats. TUSC stood in the [[Eastleigh by-election, 2013|Eastleigh by-election]]. Candidate Daz Procter achieved 0.15% of the vote. Up to mid-November 2013, TUSC had contested 27 council by-elections in 2013 (with candidates in place for ten more). TUSC’s average percentage share of the vote in these seats was just under 6%. Joe Robinson won a seat for TUSC on Maltby Town Council. ==== 2012 local elections ==== TUSC stood 132 candidates in 38 councils, with 17 candidates for the [[Greater London Assembly]]. Two TUSC-backed candidates were elected, [[Michael Lavalette]] in [[Preston City Council election, 2012|Preston]] and Peter Smith in [[Walsall]].TUSC 2012 local election results http://www.tusc.org.uk/press030512.php In the council elections in England and Wales TUSC candidates averaged 6.2% of the poll. [[Tony Mulhearn]], one of the 47 Liverpool Councillors who refused to set a budget for the council, and led a campaign of defiance of the Conservative government in the 1980s stood as the candidate for Mayor of Liverpool, coming fifth with 4.86% of the vote. In Scotland, 38 candidates stood in nine councils as the Scottish Anti-Cuts Coalition (SACC).TUSC candidates in the 2012 elections http://www.tusc.org.uk/press110412.php The TUSC campaign for the Greater London Assembly was launched by Bob Crow of the RMT and [[Matt Wrack]] of the [[Fire Brigades Union|FBU]],GLA Election campaign launch http://www.tusc.org.uk/london_tusc.php and candidates included Alex Gordon, President of the RMT trade union and April Ashley a member of the UNISON National Executive. TUSC stood candidates in the 2012 by-elections for [[Manchester Central by-election, 2012|Manchester Central]] (garnering 1.3%), [[Middlesbrough by-election, 2012|Middlesbrough]] (1.6%) and [[Rotherham by-election, 2012|Rotherham]] (1.3%). ==== 2011 local elections ==== TUSC stood 174 candidates in the May 2011 council elections.{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/candidates.php|title=TUSC candidates for May council elections 2011 – regional breakdown|publisher=TUSC|accessdate=1 May 2011}} In 13 seats TUSC polled over 10% and in over a quarter polled more than 5%. The average vote was 50.2%. ===== 2011 Welsh Assembly election ===== TUSC stood a total number of 24 candidates out of two Welsh Assembly regions in the [[National Assembly for Wales election, 2011|2011 Welsh Assembly elections]] in which it came 10th place out of 11 parties in the [[South Wales West (National Assembly for Wales electoral region)|South Wales West]] region with 809 votes (0.5%) and for the [[South Wales Central (National Assembly for Wales electoral region)|South Wales Central]] region, it came 11th place out of 12 parties with 830 votes (0.4%). It gained 1,639 votes in total with 0.2% nationwide. ==TUSC constituent organisations== Each of TUSC's constituent organisations are entitled to representation on the national steering committee and engage in decision-making regarding policy, strategy, and the selection of candidates. They include: *[[Socialist Party (England and Wales)|Socialist Party]] *[[Socialist Party Scotland]] *[[National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers]] *[[Solidarity (Scotland)|Solidarity]] *[[Socialist Workers Party (UK)|Socialist Workers Party]] (Scottish TUSC only) ===Other organisations currently or previously linked to TUSC=== *DayMer{{cite news|title=2014 local elections: The TUSC results|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/txt/307.pdf|accessdate=25 March 2016|work=TUSC|date=27 May 2014|format=PDF}} *Hull Red Labour{{cite web|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/17068/04-03-2015/there-is-an-alternative-to-austerity-rebel-councillors-show-so-could-you-be-a-candidate |title=There Is An Alternative To Austerity Rebel Councillors Show So Could You Be A Candidate |publisher=Tusc.org.uk |date=2015-03-04 |accessdate=2018-04-07}} *[[Labour Representation Committee (2004)|Labour Representation Committee]] *[[Left Unity (UK)|Left Unity]] *Leicester Independent Councillors Against the Cuts *[[Pan-African Congress]]{{cite news|title=Local elections 2014: The TUSC results in full|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/17003/30-05-2014/local-elections-2014-the-tusc-results-in-full|accessdate=25 March 2016|work=TUSC official website|date=30 May 2014}} *[[Respect Party]] *[[Socialist Resistance]] *[[Southampton City Council election, 2015|Southampton Councillors Against Cuts]]{{cite web|title=TUSC councillors lay down fight-back challenge to Labour – who wave white flag in reply|url=http://www.tusc.org.uk/16869/26-11-2013/tusc-councillors-lay-down-fight-back-challenge-to-labour-who-wave-white-flag-in-reply|website=TUSC|accessdate=25 March 2016|date=26 November 2013}} Clarice Talisman Castle | family = [[Mark Pears]] (brother)
David Pears (brother)
[[Bernard Pears]] (grandfather) | website = }} '''Sir Trevor Steven Pears''' [[Order of St Michael and St George|CMG]] (born 18 June 1964) is a British businessman and [[philanthropist]]. He is the executive chairman of the [[Pears Foundation]], the family foundation he set up in 1992 with his two brothers, Mark and David. ==Early life== Trevor Pears is the son of Clive Pears and Clarice Talisman Castle (1933–1999), and the grandson of [[Bernard Pears]].{{cite news|last1=Boggan|first1=Steve|title=Secretive world of landlady who is richer than the Queen|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/secretive-world-of-landlady-who-is-richer-than-the-queen-1159056.html|accessdate=23 February 2015|work=The Independent|date=18 May 1998}}{{cite news|last1=Murray|first1=Paula|title=EXCLUSIVE: Scots city to receive £100k due to charity’s family ties|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/544522/Glasgow-receive-100k-due-charity-family-ties-Pear-Foundation|accessdate=3 October 2015|work=Sunday Express|date=7 December 2014}} Clarice Talisman Castle was born in and grew up in Lochside Street, Shawlands, Glasgow, the daughter of Abraham Castle, a dealer in electrical and wireless appliances, and his wife Hannah. Born to a [[British Jewish|Jewish]] family, he inherited along with his brothers [[Mark Pears|Mark]] and David, a multi-billion pound property empire, the [[William Pears Group]], founded by his father and grandfather.[http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/122424/jc-power-100-2014 Jewish Chronicle: "JC Power 100 2014 - Trevor Pears"] 10 September 2014 He was educated at the private [[City of London School for Boys]], followed by [[City University London|City Polytechnic]], where he studied law.{{cite news|title=Let's all make it a bumper year for good causes, says man who gave away £30m|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/lets-all-make-it-a-bumper-year-for-good-causes-says-man-who-gave-away-30m-7442487.html|accessdate=4 October 2015|work=Evening Standard|date=13 February 2012}} ==Career== Pears oversees the strategic direction of the Foundation,{{cite web|last1=Quinn|first1=James|title=Pears family comes out of the property shadows|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/profiles/8569562/Pears-family-comes-out-of-the-property-shadows.html|website=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=30 October 2017}}{{cite web|title=Trevor Pears receives Knighthood|url=http://ejewishphilanthropy.com/trevor-pears-receives-knighthood/|website=ejewishphilanthropy.com|accessdate=30 October 2017}} which is concerned with positive identity and citizenship and seeks to build respect and understanding between people of different backgrounds and faiths; investing in programmes in the UK, Israel and the developing world.{{cite web|last1=Dyson|first1=Rob|title=Pears Foundation extends vital funding to Pennies|url=http://pennies.org.uk/pears-foundation/|website=pennies.org.uk|accessdate=30 October 2017}}{{cite web|title=Pears Foundation|url=http://www.iataskforce.org/entities/view/264|website=iataskforce.org|accessdate=30 October 2017}}{{cite web|title=Pears Foundation Central African Interfaith Peacebuilding Partnership (CIPP)|url=https://partnerships.usaid.gov/resource-partner/pears-foundation|website=partnerships.usaid.gov|accessdate=30 October 2017}} The Foundation has also partnered with the [[British Council]], [[British embassy|British Embassy in Israel]], and UJIA to fund research into treating diabetes, heart disease, leukaemia, anaemia and Alzheimer’s.{{cite web|last1=Welch|first1=Ben|title=£1.5m boost for Israeli and UK scientists combating disease|url=https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/1-5m-boost-for-israeli-and-uk-scientists-combating-disease-1.450241|website=thejc.com|accessdate=19 April 2018}} ==Personal life== He lives in Hampstead, London, with his wife Daniela and their three children. In 2005, he donated £20,000 to [[David Cameron]]'s Tory leadership campaign. In 2014, Daniela Pears was appointed as mayoress of Camden. She is also a trustee of the Jewish charity [[Mitzvah Day]].{{cite web|author=Tim Lamden and Ekin Karasin |url=http://www.hamhigh.co.uk/news/politics/jewish_charity_trustee_and_billionaire_s_wife_becomes_camden_mayoress_1_3646001 |title=Jewish charity trustee and billionaire’s wife becomes Camden mayoress - Politics - Hampstead Highgate Express |publisher=Hamhigh.co.uk |date= |accessdate=17 June 2017}} ==Honours== Pears is a fellow of Birkbeck, University of London and was appointed [[Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] (CMG) in the 2011 New Year Honours for services to the community and UK/Israel relations.{{London Gazette |issue=59647 |date=31 December 2010|page=3|supp=y}} Pears remains a director of his family business, the [[William Pears Group]]. He was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[2017 Birthday Honours]] for services to philanthropy.{{London Gazette|issue=61962|supp=y|page=B2|date=17 June 2017}}{{cite web|last=Wilson |first=Kay |url=http://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/honours-2017/ |title=Natasha Kaplinsky honoured for services to Holocaust education | Jewish News |publisher=Jewishnews.timesofisrael.com |date=1 April 1945 |accessdate=17 June 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.pearsfoundation.org.uk Pears Foundation website] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pears, Trevor}} [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:British philanthropists]] [[Category:British Jews]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) donors]] {{UK-business-bio-stub}}
